english: Perfect; flawless (na-noun/na-adjective: 完璧だ／完璧なN). Often used for plans, results, performances, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>計画<rt>けいかく</rt></ruby>は<ruby>完璧<rt>かんぺき</rt></ruby>だ。

english: A tearful voice (noun), describing speech that sounds like someone is about to cry; can also be used predicatively as 涙声だ.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>涙声<rt>なみだごえ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>謝<rt>あやま</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: She apologized in a tearful voice.

english: A seat; also an occasion/setting (e.g., a meeting or a meal), as in 夕食の席 “at the dinner table/occasion.”
japanese_example: <ruby>夕食<rt>ゆうしょく</rt></ruby>の<ruby>席<rt>せき</rt></ruby>でその<ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>が<ruby>話題<rt>わだい</rt></ruby>になった。
english_example: That topic came up at the dinner table.

english: Witty; smart; thoughtfully considerate (attributive form), often for replies, remarks, or actions (e.g., 気の利いた返事).
japanese_example: <ruby>気<rt>き</rt></ruby>の<ruby>利<rt>き</rt></ruby>いた<ruby>返事<rt>へんじ</rt></ruby>ができた。
english_example: I managed to give a witty reply.

english: Flattery; compliment (often implying insincerity). Commonly: お世辞を言う／お世辞にも〜ない.
japanese_example: <ruby>お世辞<rt>おせじ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>うつもりはない。
english_example: I don’t intend to flatter you.

english: Sentence-final ending meaning “I wonder …,” adding a soft, self-directed tone to a question.
japanese_example: <ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>かいい<ruby>案<rt>あん</rt></ruby>はあるかな？
english_example: I wonder if there are any good ideas.

english: Honorific verb for 行く・来る・いる, used to show respect to the subject (e.g., 先生はいらっしゃいます).
japanese_example: <ruby>先生<rt>せんせい</rt></ruby>は<ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby><ruby>研究室<rt>けんきゅうしつ</rt></ruby>にいらっしゃいます。
english_example: The professor is in the lab now.

japanese: 素晴らしいゴルファーでいらっしゃる
hiragana: すばらしいごるふぁーでいらっしゃる
english: Honorific phrasing meaning “(someone) is a wonderful golfer.” でいらっしゃる functions as a respectful equivalent of です.
japanese_example: <ruby>社長<rt>しゃちょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>素晴<rt>すば</rt></ruby>らしいゴルファーでいらっしゃいます。
english_example: The company president is a wonderful golfer.

english: Lovely; stylish; wonderful (na-adjective: 素敵なN／素敵だ). Common for clothes, places, experiences, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>素敵<rt>すてき</rt></ruby>な<ruby>服<rt>ふく</rt></ruby>ですね。

english: Honorific term for clothing (especially “your clothing”). Often used in polite compliments or service settings.
japanese_example: <ruby>お召<rt>め</rt></ruby>し<ruby>物<rt>もの</rt></ruby>がとても<ruby>素敵<rt>すてき</rt></ruby>です。

english: Emphatic word in questions meaning “what on earth; just what,” expressing surprise, annoyance, or urgency.
japanese_example: いったい<ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>が<ruby>起<rt>お</rt></ruby>きたの？

english: 求める means “to seek; to request,” and in formal contexts can mean “to purchase.” お求め is a polite nominal form used in customer-service speech.
japanese_example: どちらで<ruby>お求<rt>もと</rt></ruby>めですか。

english: Honorific pattern meaning “to do” respectfully: お + verb stem + になる (e.g., お待ちになる, お探しになる).
japanese_example: <ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>を<ruby>お探<rt>さが</rt></ruby>しになるのですか。

japanese: お召し物はどこでお求めになりましたの？
hiragana: おめしものはどこでおもとめになりましたの
english: Very polite question meaning “Where did you purchase your clothes?” Uses honorific お求めになる and soft sentence ending の.
japanese_example: <ruby>お召<rt>め</rt></ruby>し<ruby>物<rt>もの</rt></ruby>はどこで<ruby>お求<rt>もと</rt></ruby>めになりましたの？
english_example: Where did you purchase your clothes?

english: Casual suggestion meaning “How about something like this, I wonder?” Used when proposing an idea gently.
japanese_example: こんな<ruby>案<rt>あん</rt></ruby>でどうかな。
english_example: How about an idea like this?

english: Respect; esteem. Commonly used as 尊敬する (to respect) and 尊敬している (to admire).
japanese_example: <ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>は<ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>尊敬<rt>そんけい</rt></ruby>している。

hiragana: そんけいするじんぶつ
english: A person you respect/admire. Often used in writing prompts or introductions (e.g., 尊敬する人物について).
japanese_example: <ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>尊敬<rt>そんけい</rt></ruby>する<ruby>人物<rt>じんぶつ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>父<rt>ちち</rt></ruby>です。
english_example: The person I respect is my father.

english: A person; figure/character (especially in history, stories, or public life), as in 歴史上の人物.
japanese_example: <ruby>歴史上<rt>れきしじょう</rt></ruby>の<ruby>人物<rt>じんぶつ</rt></ruby>について<ruby>調<rt>しら</rt></ruby>べた。

english: A composition; essay (often school writing). Commonly: 作文を書く.
japanese_example: <ruby>作文<rt>さくぶん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>書<rt>か</rt></ruby>く。

english: Indicates an externally decided outcome: “it has been decided that …” Often implies a rule, schedule, or decision not made solely by the speaker.
japanese_example: <ruby>学校<rt>がっこう</rt></ruby>で<ruby>作文<rt>さくぶん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>書<rt>か</rt></ruby>くことになっている。
english_example: At school, it’s been decided that we write essays.

japanese: 学校で尊敬する人物について作文を書くことになって、あなたのことを書きました
hiragana: がっこうでそんけいするじんぶつについてさくぶんをかくことになってあなたのことをかきました
english: Means “At school it was decided we’d write an essay about someone we respect, and I wrote about you,” using ことになって for an external assignment/decision.
japanese_example: <ruby>学校<rt>がっこう</rt></ruby>で<ruby>尊敬<rt>そんけい</rt></ruby>する<ruby>人物<rt>じんぶつ</rt></ruby>について<ruby>作文<rt>さくぶん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>書<rt>か</rt></ruby>くことになって、あなたのことを<ruby>書<rt>か</rt></ruby>きました。
english_example: At school, it was decided we’d write an essay about someone we respect, and I wrote about you.

english: “It was too perfect/too good to be true,” implying something seemed unrealistically well-made or convenient. Often used as 出来過ぎだ／出来過ぎだった.
japanese_example: <ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>が<ruby>出来過<rt>できす</rt></ruby>ぎだった。

english: Deep emotion from being moved or impressed; “to be deeply touched.” Often: 感激する／感激した.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>言葉<rt>ことば</rt></ruby>に<ruby>感激<rt>かんげき</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I was deeply moved by his words.

english: To burst into tears; to start crying (suddenly). Pattern: Vます-stem + 出す for “begin abruptly.”
japanese_example: <ruby>子供<rt>こども</rt></ruby>が<ruby>急<rt>きゅう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>泣<rt>な</rt></ruby>き<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: The child suddenly burst into tears.

english: To hold/embrace (だく); also “to harbor” a feeling/idea (often written 抱く, reading いだく in that sense).
japanese_example: <ruby>赤<rt>あか</rt></ruby>ちゃんを<ruby>抱<rt>だ</rt></ruby>いた。

english: To hug tightly; to hold someone close with affection or relief.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>強<rt>つよ</rt></ruby>く<ruby>抱<rt>だ</rt></ruby>きしめた。

english: To slip/dive into; to crawl into (e.g., bedcovers, a narrow space). Often used with 布団, ベッド, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>布団<rt>ふとん</rt></ruby>に<ruby>潜<rt>もぐ</rt></ruby>り<ruby>込<rt>こ</rt></ruby>んだ。

hiragana: おおわらいするところ
english: “About to burst into laughter.” V辞書形 + ところ indicates the moment just before doing something.
japanese_example: <ruby>危<rt>あぶ</rt></ruby>なく<ruby>大笑<rt>おおわら</rt></ruby>いするところだった。

english: Kid; brat (rough/derogatory), used by an older speaker to look down on a boy/young person.
japanese_example: あの<ruby>小僧<rt>こぞう</rt></ruby>がまた<ruby>来<rt>き</rt></ruby>た。

english: Desperately; frantically; with all one’s might. Often used with actions like 走る, 探す, 守る.
japanese_example: <ruby>必死<rt>ひっし</rt></ruby>で<ruby>走<rt>はし</rt></ruby>った。

english: Ordinary; normal; usual(ly). Used as a noun/na-adjective/adverb depending on context (普通だ／普通のN／普通に).
japanese_example: <ruby>普通<rt>ふつう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>朝<rt>あさ</rt></ruby><ruby>七時<rt>しちじ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>起<rt>お</rt></ruby>きる。
english_example: I usually get up at 7 a.m.

english: Te-form of 装う: “to pretend; to put on an appearance; to disguise (as).” Often with 〜ふりを装う.
japanese_example: <ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>も<ruby>知<rt>し</rt></ruby>らないふりを<ruby>装<rt>よそお</rt></ruby>って<ruby>話<rt>はな</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I spoke while pretending not to know anything.

english: To come out; to appear; to emerge (often from inside to outside, or something becomes noticeable). Also used figuratively (ideas/tears come out).
japanese_example: <ruby>涙<rt>なみだ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>出<rt>で</rt></ruby>てくる。

english: Absolutely; utterly; completely (emphatic, somewhat formal). Often used with agreement or evaluation, e.g., 全くもって同感だ.
japanese_example: <ruby>全<rt>まった</rt></ruby>くもって<ruby>同感<rt>どうかん</rt></ruby>だ。

english: Imperative of する is しろ (a strong command). Used for blunt orders (e.g., 早く準備しろ).
japanese_example: <ruby>早<rt>はや</rt></ruby>く<ruby>準備<rt>じゅんび</rt></ruby>しろ。

english: Full of force/feeling; charged with emotion or emphasis. Commonly modifies voice/words: 力がこもった声.
japanese_example: <ruby>力<rt>ちから</rt></ruby>がこもった<ruby>声<rt>こえ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>訴<rt>うった</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: He appealed in a forceful, emotion-filled voice.

english: The dinner table/occasion; the setting of a meal where conversation or events occur.
japanese_example: <ruby>夕食<rt>ゆうしょく</rt></ruby>の<ruby>席<rt>せき</rt></ruby>で<ruby>発表<rt>はっぴょう</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I announced it at the dinner table.

english: Splendid; excellent; wonderful (i-adjective). Used for achievements, experiences, people, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>素晴<rt>すば</rt></ruby>らしい<ruby>成果<rt>せいか</rt></ruby>だ。

english: Casual “I wonder if there’s something,” used as a soft self-question (かな adds a gentle, wondering tone).
japanese_example: <ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>かあるかな？
